subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery
with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
This is part two of my series on,
“Living in the Afterlife.”
I'm here with… Myself. We're going to be talking
about identity in the afterlife. It's
really a crucial question
because, after all, once you die
your body is gone.
As the Buddhists say, “Try to talk but you have no
tongue, try to hear but you have no ears,
try to see but you have no eyes, try to
swallow but there's no mouth.”
We get from this
a very peculiar situation. It creates
enormous problems philosophically.
Not just philosophically, I think you
[also] have to say emotionally
for the newly deceased person. Now,
the irony is, many people who are newly- deceased…
Don't even know that they're dead yet,
because it feels so alive!
They don't necessarily have a body.
They're not necessarily
breathing but they're there. There's a presence
there. In fact, I recall an interesting story of
communication with someone who was
trying to commit suicide. They just
kept saying, “I can't die. I want to die, I
want to get it over with,
but whatever I do, I'm still here.”
The question then is, who is here?
How are you here without a body? There
are certain skeptical
philosophers… That's a funny phrase,
skeptical philosophers, because
there are so many nuances to both words,
skeptical and philosopher. In any
case, there are philosophers who would say,
“Without a body, there can be no identity.”
There is a sense in which that is
true. You need a boundary, you need an
inside and an outside,
you need a membrane, so to speak.
Which is why my good friend Bernardo
Kastrup suggests that in
order to explain the fact that we all share the
one mind that sees through the eyes of
every living creature, that that
is our deepest level of identity, that's
who we are—
how do we account for the fact that we
seem so separate, so individual? He suggests it's
similar to the way in which a person
with multiple personality disorder—
commonly thought of these days as dissociative
identity disorder—forms their own
identity: a dissociative
boundary forms. Even within a single
person you can have multiple personalities,
so why not individual identities within
the great cosmic mind?
Bernardo would say…
Bernardo would say that when you die and
your body is gone, the dissociative boundary
is probably gone as well. The contents
of your consciousness merge into the great
cosmic mind. You become one with
everything. People who have near-death experiences
often report this greatly expanded
sense of self. It does seem like they're
merging with the ultimate consciousness.
They feel an overpowering sense of love
beyond anything earthly or human.
It sounds wonderful. But if they
merge with that great oneness, how do
they ever return?
If they come back from a near-death experience
the body, I guess, reasserts itself in some way.
But there is another way to look at it, and that
is that there are many bodies. The
esoteric traditions, for example, talk about the
astral body, the etheric body, the
mental body, the causal body, the Buddhist body.
There are different options. If you get
into Kabbalah they talk about
Ein-Sof Ohr, the invisible light,
that ultimately we are energy beings, we
are light beings.
Here we are, it seems as if, for many people, we
are our body. I think that
is true in a way. We are our body. It is
very hard to separate
us from the body. But you have to admit
that the body itself is probably hyper-
dimensional.
We are looking at ourselves
in three-space. You're watching a
video image of me. It's flat, it’s a two-space
image. If I were here in front of you,
you'd see me in three dimensions.
But what if there are infinitely many dimensions
and you can see it at different
levels. You might see a 12-dimensional person,
a 256–dimensional person,
a thousand-dimensional person, a million-
dimensional person, a billion-dimensional person.
So hey, if I have a billion
dimensions, I can let go of these three. I’ve
still got a lot left.
There are many, many possibilities. I
think it's fair to say that our
human consciousness can only very
dimly perceive what might be
possible in these worlds.
Rudolf Steiner, as I recall, once asked
the question, “How do you distinguish one spirit
from another?”
In his case, when he talks about Ahriman, the
Persian deity, “Angryman,” as my friend
Jason used to say—
angry man.
The distinction between, let's say,
angry-man and Jesus Christ—they must seem like
very different spiritual entities
which would suggest,
if they are in fact separate, they have separate
dissociative boundaries in the invisible
world, in the supra
sensible world. Since you've used that
phrase, supra sensible world,
let's explore that for a moment. It implies
that there is another world completely
outside of human sensory experience but
ontologically real. For starters, doesn't that
imply a leap, an
ontological leap, to postulate that there's
some real world that we don't perceive
through the senses? No,
not at all. What we perceive
most directly is our own
consciousness. Most of us are not in
the habit of looking deeply within. I've been
playing, exploring with it for the last
50 years and I barely get anywhere.
You can look at your dreams, you can
meditate, you can have psychedelic experiences.
People who are very gifted might have an out-of-
body experience. Basically,
there's this great consciousness. I
recall as a child
hearing somebody say, “You know, we are all
God deep inside.” I
thought to myself, “What? I'm God
deep inside?” I'd never experienced or felt
anything like that. But I think we have such vast
potential. We barely scratch the surface of who we
are. Yet who we are is, as Carl Jung once said,
ultimate metaphysical reality. The ground of
being itself is who we are at a deep level…
at a deep, deep, deep, deep level. And yet,
here I'm talking into a video camera
right now. I'm looking at my own
image, the image that you're probably seeing.
I'm looking at that image right now and
that looks very discreet. That looks very
separate. That looks very tiny and minuscule
as compared to the ground of being of
the universe of
everything. How is it possible that we
can be these little specks on a tiny little planet
in a tiny little galaxy in a great big universe
and yet we can be one with everything at the
same time? It superficially
makes no sense. At this point we have to
begin to think about the
evolution of consciousness, the evolution of what
Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz called
the monad. The monad is
an individual self. Leibniz suggested that
monads are the fundamental units of reality,
conscious monads. I can't say I
understand Leibniz's entire thinking about
what he called monadology, the study of the
creation, the evolution, the prognosis, so
to speak, of being a monad. He seemed to
suggest that
monads go from the very tiny to the very large.
As one of his critics said, “You mean there are
millions of monads in a drop of urine?”
But the suggestion is that we're all
on a path, all of us little monads. We are all
evolving. It happens
step by step and yet it happens outside of
time as well.
Ram Dass once said, “There's nothing to
strive for, you're already there, you're
already enlightened!”
Yet, at the same time, we're caught in time,
another apparent illusion.
People who have a near-death experience and
are in the afterlife report that in a
matter of moments—maybe minutes, maybe
even hours—but in a short time
they experience their entire lifetime instant by
instant, as if they're reliving it. They are
not only reliving it from within the memories of
themselves, but reliving their lives
through the eyes of everyone else they've
touched. I take this literally.
There are too many reports like this to ignore.
What it ultimately suggests is that
in that realm of consciousness—in that super
sensible bardo plane where people are having the
past life review—
it's vibrating, you could say, at a faster pace,
much, much faster. Which is why what seems like
moments, minutes, maybe hours to us
can be an entire lifetime experience
on that plane. It suggests
that when we understand it better—and I
believe we're right on the cusp
of beginning to explore these things in a major
scientific way—we'll be able to ask:
how does it happen that at one level, time is so
different than at another level? Does it
mean everything is vibrating faster?
What does it mean when the theosophists,
for example, talk about the etheric plane,
the astral plane, the mental plane, that
each in their own way is physical in the
sense of being real,
but not physical the way we think of
physical, made out of atoms and molecules,
the way our physical science describes things. We don't have a good
physical science description of astral,
material, and mental bodies, but
perhaps yet we will. And why shouldn't we?
You're getting
back to the question of identity at some
level. What does it mean
to have all of these possibilities of
different identities? Identity
as a human? When I die, however, Jeffrey Mishlove
will be dead. Whitley Strieber's wife, Anne,
who communicates with him from beyond the grave
suggests, “I'm not ‘Anne’ anymore.” She says,
“But I'll always be ‘Anne’
to you.” So there's a
sense in which Anne is now a much larger
individual, but not necessarily as large
as the entire cosmos, as large as all and
everything. There are stages along
the way that we pass through.
One of the great books about all of this
is called, The Road to Immortality, written
ostensibly by the deceased
psychical researcher Frederic Myers
and channeled through a great automatic
writer, Geraldine Cummins. One of the points Myers
makes is that there are—I think the best word
for it would be oversouls—that we
partake of not only our individual
personality, but we partake of a range of higher
selves.
The higher self, it could be an oversoul,
could be responsible, according to Myers,
for anywhere from 20 to a thousand persons
at a time. Which suggests that
you and I, although we think of ourselves
as autonomous individuals—and certainly my friend
James Tunney talks a lot about the
importance of spiritual sovereignty of
each individual. Yet at the same time
as we call for our own
unique individual sovereignty—which is
very important in James’ philosophy and I think
in mine as well—individual sovereignty,
the basis of ultimate mysticism. And yet,
we may partake of
a group soul. We may partake of a group soul from our
country, the nationality, the group soul
associated with
the language that we speak. So much of our
mental life is conditioned by the words we use
and the emotional tone of our own language.
Rudolf Steiner, for example, suggests that every
thought we have is a spiritual entity.
Our oversouls are probably projecting different
thoughts into our mind and we accept
them naturally because they feel
like part of us. They probably are part of us
if we're aware of this larger oversoul.
The philosophical
problems associated with these ideas
that I am so glibly
sharing with you in a brief, maybe
15-minute monologue,
the philosophical issues raised by these
ideas are very deep.
To really explore them thoroughly would require
a massive book. One could write 800
pages about the relationship between the
individual ego
and many different levels of oversoul.
So where does that leave us? It raises
more questions than it answers. I guess that's the
point of this monologue. I think we've come to
a conclusion for now. I know there's more to say.
I’ve been jumping around a lot. I’ve been
kind of hitting highlights here. For now,
I want to thank you for being
with me. Yes, thank you for being with us.
